body:
> Which version of SkyWalking are you using?
8.3.0

> > Don't you have parameterized mechanism in your framework like SpringMVC? Such as /product/{id}, which could reduce the memory cost clearly.
> 
> Sure, we do.

Then why you still have countless endpoints? That is strange. The cache(persistent session) would only keep the data in one minute only for better performance.

> > > Don't you have parameterized mechanism in your framework like SpringMVC? Such as /product/{id}, which could reduce the memory cost clearly.
> > 
> > 
> > Sure, we do.
> 
> Then why you still have countless endpoints? That is strange. The cache(persistent session) would only keep the data in one minute only for better performance.

Actually, after I grouped the endpoints to a few groups, I can see the grouped endpoints as expected from the "Trace" tab.
but from "Dashboard" tab, in the "Current Endpoint" dropdown box we still see a lot of endpoint names including the concrete user id.  By the way, how is the metrics instances count relation to the endpoint counts?

Endpoint group configuration sample:

- service-name: api-gateway
    rules:
      - endpoint-name: /users/{userId}/properties
        regex: .*\/users\/\w+\/properties
      - endpoint-name: /weather/*
        regex: .*\/weather\/.+
      - endpoint-name: /users/{userId}/events
        regex: .*\/users\/\w+\/events
      - endpoint-name: /users/{userId}/events/*
        regex: .*\/users\/\w+\/events\/.+
      - endpoint-name: "/*"
        regex: .*\/.+

> By the way, how is the metrics instances count relation to the endpoint counts?

Nothing.

> I can see the grouped endpoints as expected from the "Trace" tab.
but from "Dashboard" tab, in the "Current Endpoint" dropdown box we still see a lot of endpoint names including the concrete user id.

They are sharing the same query. So, should not have any different. But they wouldn't be deleted before TTL reached.

@wu-sheng @buxingzhe 
If there is gateway access, the interface of the gateway will not be serialized into the style of `/product/{id}`, because the forwarding of the gateway does not go to the step of serializing the endpoint.
@zifeihan Debug finds that it is affected by the dynamic data source, but SkyWalking happend an error that affects the rollback of the main process transaction
@zifeihan For gateway yes, but the backend provided the grouping mechanism to resolve this issue.

> @zifeihan For gateway yes, but the backend provided the grouping mechanism to resolve this issue.

Ok, I get it now, thanks！

> @zifeihan Debug finds that it is affected by the dynamic data source, but SkyWalking happend an error that affects the rollback of the main process transaction

Can you help us provide a simple demo to reproduce this bug? So that I can fix this problem as soon as possible.
One more I'd like to point out is our API gateway is developed by Golang, and we use go2sky SDK to do the trace instrumentation.
@wu-sheng what kind of scenario can lead to so many EndpointPoint*Metrics instances?

> One more I'd like to point out is our API gateway is developed by Golang, and we use go2sky SDK to do the trace instrumentation.

If you have the parameterized mechanism, this should not be the concern of go2sky, right?

> what kind of scenario can lead to so many EndpointPoint*Metrics instances?

Only the number of endpoint itself. Too many names.

> If you have the parameterized mechanism, this should not be the concern of go2sky, right?

From go2sky code base , I see it just sets the raw API url path as the span operation name when the user doesn't set it explicitly.
So if we set the operation name with parameterized pattern explicitly, then the issue should be resolved?

> So if we set the operation name with parameterized pattern explicitly, then the issue should be resolved?

From my understanding, it should be. If you don't have operation names of entry spans set randomly.
The UI looks like this, @wu-sheng @hanahmily , as stated in #5988 , we need to discuss how many new metrics (compared to OAL) we want to add here.

> The UI looks like this, @wu-sheng @hanahmily , as stated in #5988 , we need to discuss how many new metrics (compared to OAL) we want to add here. > > We could get some ideas from https://grafana.com/grafana/dashboards?search=envoy
How about we add metrics service to our Istio e2e and add more checks?

> How about we add metrics service to our Istio e2e and add more checks?

I'm OK to do this

I just adding new query GraphQL level service, I want to see the access frequency of the statements of various business systems, find out the high-frequency statements of the system, and see if caching or other methods can be used to reduce access frequency, reduce database pressure, and improve system stability Sex, and just wrote elasticsearch, but nothing else 
@wu-sheng @apache/skywalking-committers

> I just adding new query GraphQL level service, I want to see the access frequency of the statements of various business systems, find out the high-frequency statements of the system, and see if caching or other methods can be used to reduce access frequency, reduce database pressure, and improve system stability Sex, and just wrote elasticsearch, but nothing else

Could you take a look what I said above? This statistic is not accurate, actually, far from accurate. Have you checked how SkyWalking inserts the data you queried.
Seems some of the tests failed, once they passed, LGTM

> > I just adding new query GraphQL level service, I want to see the access frequency of the statements of various business systems, find out the high-frequency statements of the system, and see if caching or other methods can be used to reduce access frequency, reduce database pressure, and improve system stability Sex, and just wrote elasticsearch, but nothing else
> 
> Could you take a look what I said above? This statistic is not accurate, actually, far from accurate. Have you checked how SkyWalking inserts the data you queried.

It is based on the data of Slow statement access. This does not need to be absolutely accurate, just a relative magnitude.
If the `magnitude` is correct, they this is meaningful, but sadly, the way you implemented isn't.
How should it be implemented? I accidentally closed it
Could you share the idea first about why do you need this count? Aren't the slowest SQLs the biggest issues you need to resolve?
Seems the checks passed? Please check the logs to verify the style check really invoked.

Yes, the slowest SQLs is my first priority, but the SQLs with high access frequency is also a problem I want to care about. High-frequency SQL is also one of the reasons that affect database performance, but the [No statement] shown in my screenshot is not What I care about, this will block the writing of this data in actual use

> High-frequency SQL is also one of the reasons that affect database performance, but the [No statement] shown in my screenshot is not What I care about, this will block the writing of this data in actual use

Let's separate your issues to be clear what need to do.
1. High-frequency SQL may or may not an issue. How to statistic all SQLs? Some SQLs are very long, we saw 7k length. So, if you want to discuss this deeply, you need to know what is the ID of a SQL. Because statistic is targeting for the entity which requires an ID.
2. Ignoring `[No statement]` is quite simple. Isn't it? Change the `MultiScopesAnalysisListener` to exclude this case, and provide a configuration.(Ignore could be default, I think).
3. All things you want to resolve are irrelative with this query. That is why in the open source collaboration, you should discuss first.

Yes, discussion is really necessary
1. I really want to be simple, and I didn't think about this problem carefully. As for the problem of sql id, I have no idea about this for the time being. Can you provide any suggestions?
2. I agree with this, it can be developed to ignore the configuration items, this is also easy to implement
3. So, close this pr first

> I really want to be simple, and I didn't think about this problem carefully. As for the problem of sql id, I have no idea about this for the time being. Can you provide any suggestions?

First, in the reality, the SQL must be limited by length. But to be honest, I am not sure whether this is helpful. What would you do if you know a top frequency SQL list in the service level? 

> I agree with this, it can be developed to ignore the configuration items, this is also easy to implement

This could be sent by another pull request.

That was a bug actually, it should not have worked before. This is because the `GrpcProtocol` was initialized too early, even before `agent.start`, so that when the `collectorAddress` was overrode to be empty string, the connection had been established. One other change I am not certain about, the change from plugin `require()` using the form `PluginInstaller.require('axios').default` to `require('axios').default`. The `PluginInstaller.require()` function is specifically set to run in the context of the top-level module. I did this because I had a test case (don't remember details exactly) where the skywalking plugin could not "see" a module the main app was using through its `require()` function and its dir search tree, which led to the module not being instrumented since skywalking could not `require()` it from where it was. So I added this function so that skywalking can `require()` in the same exact way the main module does and sees everything that it does.

[EDIT}: There is also the possibility when using skywalking via. `npm link` that it may have its own different version / instance of a module compared to the main executing application (which again would wind up not instrumenting the modules the main app is using). Basically anything that is going to be instrumented, and even some stuff that may not be (like probably on-finish), should be required from the point of view of the top-level module to make sure it is the same as the top-level module uses.

I am preemptively sending you my test suite since I will probably be asleep by the time you see all of this. Also you need to explicitly `npm install` or `npm link` whatever skywalking you are using.
